You may stop if you can do so safely.

question: What does this traffic light mean?

You must stop.
Traffic may proceed if the way is clear.

question: What colour traffic light comes on after the green?

Green arrow.
Amber only.

Oncoming traffic is waiting to make a left turn.

question: What does a flashing left amber arrow at a traffic light mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters

A driver may turn left.
A driver may proceed straight ahead.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters

questions: U-turn not permitted.
Reversing not permitted.
Slippery road ahead.
Two-way traffic prohibited.

question: What colour traffic light comes on after a non-flashing amber light?

explanation: Explantion: The normal sequence of traffic lights is red-green-amber.

questions: Stop and give way to pedestrians - proceed if the way is clear.
You are entering a special speed limit area.
Danger ahead - you must stop and wait until they stop flashing.
Drivers have right-of-way.
answer: Stop and give way to pedestrians - proceed if the way is clear.

question: What is the maximum permissible speed for cars or motorcycles on motorways?

80 km/h.

80 km/h.

question: What is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a caravan on national roads?

60 km/h.

80 km/h.

question: Where must a driver not park?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters

Where there is a broken white line along the centre of the road.
Where there are two broken white lines along the centre of the road.
On a single yellow line outside the times indicated.
answer: Where there is a continuous white along the centre of the road.

question: What distance before a zebra crossing is parking prohibited?

15 meters.

20 meters.

question: Within what distance of a junction is parking prohibited?

questions: 5 meters.
8 meters.
3 meters.
15 meters.

question: When may a driver park a vehicle in a loading bay?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: Loading bays are provided to enable goods vehicles to load or unload goods, up to a maximum of 30 minutes. Only goods vehicles are permitted to use loading bays.
questions: Park for a maximum of 5 minutes.
Park for a maximum of 30 minutes.
Park for a maximum of 10 minutes.
When the driver is the driver of a goods vehicle and is loading or unloading.
answer: When the driver is the driver of a goods vehicle and is loading or unloading.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 30km/h
questions: Maximum speed is 30 km/h.
Parking not allowed for more than 30 minutes.
Distance to junction is 30 meters.

question: Is a driver permitted to park at an entrance to a property?

For a maximum of 15 minutes at any one time.

question: When is parking permitted on a footpath?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: It is always an offence to park on a footpath. Where a vehicle is parked on a footpath, pedestrians may have to step onto the road to go around the vehicle and so place themselves in danger.

When at least half the footpath remains free for pedestrians.
When cars are parked both sides of the road.
answer: It is never permitted to park on a footpath.

heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: Double parking is never permitted. Parking is never permitted where it might interfere in any way with the normal flow through traffic or obstruct or endanger other road users.
questions: When there are double white lines.
Double parking is never permitted.
When there are double yellow lines.
When there is a hard shoulder.
answer: Double parking is never permitted.

question: When is parking permitted at a taxi rank?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: Stopping or parking within an area marked as taxi rank is prohibited as this may obstruct taxis entering or leaving the rank.
questions: When parking for less than 15 minutes.
When waiting to collect passengers from a taxi.
When the rank is unoccupied.
Parking at a taxi rank is prohibited.
answer: Parking at a taxi rank is prohibited.

question: When is parking permitted at a sharp bend?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: Parking is never permitted where it might interfere in any way with the normal flow through traffic or obstruct or endanger other road users - for example, by forcing other drivers into the path of oncoming traffic.
questions: When you put on your hazard warning lights.
Parking is never permitted at a sharp bend.
Provided you park no more than 45 centimeters from the kerb or edge of the road.
When drivers coming from behind can see your vehicle.
answer: Parking is never permitted at a sharp bend.

question: When is parking permitted on the brow of a hill?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: Parking on the brow of a hill or on a humpbacked bridge is prohibited. Parking in such a place may restrict the zone of vision of drivers approaching the hill and force them into the path of oncoming traffic.
questions: When you angle the wheels towards the kerb.
When it has an efficient handbrake.
Only when there is no traffic on the road.
Parking on the brow of a hill is never allowed.
answer: Parking on the brow of a hill is never allowed.

question: If there is no footpath, where must a pedestrian walk?

questions: Right-hand side of the road.
1 meter from the edge.
There is no regulation.
Left-hand side of the road.
answer: Right-hand side of the road.

question: On a narrow busy road, what rules apply to pedestrians when walking?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: Pedestrians should walk in single file on busy narrow roads. Drivers should be aware of the Rules of the Road for pedestrians, drive with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.
questions: Two abreast.
Walk in single file.
Not more than two abreast.
Three abreast.
answer: Walk in single file.

question: When should pedestrians wear reflective clothing at night?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: Outside built-up areas, pedestrians should wear reflective clothing at all times when walking at night. This is particularly important where there is no street lighting and no footpath for pedestrians.

Inside urban areas.
At all times outside well-lit urban areas.
Where no street lighting is provided.
answer: At all times outside well-lit urban areas.

question: What road users must comply with traffic lights (including pedestrian lights)?

Overhanging load.
Slow vehicle in front.
Livestock unloading.
answer: Overhanging load.

question: When are lighting up hours?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: Lighting up hours are defined as the period of time during which drivers should turn on dipped headlights in order to be seen. This period normally starts half an hour after sunset and ends half an hour before sunrise.

From mid-night until 6 a.m.
From just after dusk to just before dawn.
When visibility is less than 300 meters.
answer: From just after dusk to just before dawn.

heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: Drivers need to see and be seen during all periods of low light levels - for example, at dusk and dawn and in some bad weather conditions. At times of low light, you should turn on dipped headlights. The Road Safety Authority recommends that motorcyclists and drivers turn on their dipped headlights or daytime running lights during daylight hours.
questions: Dipped headlights.
No lights.
Full headlamps.
Fog lamps.
answer: Dipped headlights.

heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters

questions: To alert the driver to road flooding ahead.
To slow down traffic in the vicinity.
To prioritise heavy goods traffic.
To reduce tyre wear.
answer: To slow down traffic in the vicinity.

Cyclists and users of motorised wheelchairs.

question: What is the correct action to take in this situation?

question: What does this sign mean?

question: What should the driver do if children are playing at the edge of the roadway?

question: What does this sign mean?

explanation: Explantion: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 100km/h.

question: What should a driver do in this situation?
heading: Alert Driving and Consideration
explanation: Explantion: When approaching a zebra crossing, you must yield to pedestrians already on or about to cross the road.
questions: Allow the pedestrian to cross the road.
Sound your horn and drive on.
Wait at the zebra crossing until the van has turned off.
Accelerate quickly to clear the crossing.
answer: Allow the pedestrian to cross the road.

question: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
heading: Alert Driving and Consideration
explanation: Explantion: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations - in this case paying attention to the warning sign clearly indicating a right-hand bend ahead.
questions: A minor road to the left ahead.
A dangerous right-hand bend.
A minor road to the right ahead.
A sharp dip in the road ahead.
answer: A dangerous right-hand bend.

question: What must a driver be prepared for in this situation?
heading: Alert Driving and Consideration
explanation: Explantion: When you are approaching road works, you should be prepared to divert around or through them and drive at a slower speed. At road works, the road surface may be uneven or dirty.
questions: An area where there is cattle on the road.
Turning left ahead because of road works.
An area where signals are not given.
Road workers crossing ahead.
answer: Turning left ahead because of road works.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: A Taxi Rank sign indicates that this is an area reserved for taxis, and parking is not permitted here.
questions: Appointed rank for taxis.
You may park when the rank is empty.
You may pick up or set down passengers.
Only taxis may turn right or left ahead.
answer: Appointed rank for taxis.

question: What should a driver who wants to turn right do in this situation?
heading: Alert Driving and Consideration
explanation: Explantion: As you approach a junction where you want to turn right, you should read the road ahead and take up the correct position for turning in good time.
questions: Carefully turn to the left after sounding the horn.
Proceed straight ahead and take a wide turn to the right.
Reverse and get into the right lane.
Proceed straight ahead or turn left.
answer: Proceed straight ahead or turn left.

question: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a right turn from the major road into the minor road?
heading: Alert Driving and Consideration
explanation: Explantion: The correct position from which to turn right from a major road to a minor road is just left of centre. You should take up the correct position in good time and avoid cutting the corner or 'swan necking' - that is going beyond the turning point as car 2 is in the picture.
questions: Car 1 is in the correct position to make the right turn.
Car 2 is in the correct position to make the right turn.
Car 3 is in the correct position to make the right turn.
Car 4 is in the correct position to make the right turn.
answer: Car 3 is in the correct position to make the right turn.

question: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a left turn from a minor road onto a major road?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: The correct position from which to turn left from a minor road to a major road is to keep close to the left-hand side of the roadway as you can safely. When turning left, do not swing wide or mount the kerb.
questions: Car 1 is in the correct position to make the left turn.
Car 2 is in the correct position to make the left turn.
Car 3 is in the correct position to make the left turn.
Car 4 is in the correct position to make the left turn.
answer: Car 2 is in the correct position to make the left turn.

question: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a right turn from a minor road onto a major road?
heading: Alert Driving and Consideration
explanation: Explantion: The correct position from which to turn right from a minor road to a major road is just left of centre of the road. You should take up the correct position in good time and complete the turn by entering the left-hand side of the major road.
questions: Car 1 is in the correct position to turn right
Car 2 is in the correct position to turn right
Car 3 is in the correct position to turn right
Car 4 is in the correct position to turn right
answer: Car 1 is in the correct position to turn right

question: What should the driver do when there is a sharp dip in the road ahead?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: As you approach a sharp dip in the road, you should be aware that there might be hidden dangers ahead. For example, there might be pedestrians, cyclists or other approaching traffic, or the road could be flooded in the clip. You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations - you might need to reduce your speed and drive with extra care.
questions: Move to the centre of the road in order to avoid a vehicle that may be parked on the left.
Flash your lights to warn oncoming drivers of your presence.
Reduce your speed, keep to the left and be alert for hazards ahead.
Increase your speed.
answer: Reduce your speed, keep to the left and be alert for hazards ahead.

question: What should a driver do if they see a red warning triangle on the road?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: Warning triangles are used to alert approaching traffic that there is a vehicle breakdown or collision ahead. When you come across a warning triangle, you should slow down and prepare to stop if necessary. Do not allow yourself to be distracted by the incident.
questions: Stop and await instructions.
The driver should slow down and expect a hazard up ahead.
Avoid it, maintain speed and carry on.
Stop at the triangle before proceeding.
answer: The driver should slow down and expect a hazard up ahead.

question: The driver is approaching traffic lights that they know have been green for some time. What should the driver do?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. Where traffic lights have been green for some time, you should be prepared to stop, as the lights are probably about to change to amber.
questions: The driver should prepare to stop in case the lights change before they reach them.
Accelerate to clear them before they change.
Maintain the current speed.
Maintain the current speed and sound your horn as you approach.
answer: The driver should prepare to stop in case the lights change before they reach them.

question: What should a driver do when approaching a junction normally controlled by traffic lights and the traffic lights are not lighting?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. If the traffic lights are not working, you should approach the junction with extra care, and you should proceed only if it is safe to do so.
questions: Treat the junction as an unmarked junction and proceed cautiously while watching out for other traffic.
Drive smartly through the junction to avoid delay.
Stop at the junction and give way to traffic on your left.
Switch on the hazard warning lights and drive on.
answer: Treat the junction as an unmarked junction and proceed cautiously while watching out for other traffic.

question: What should the driver do if there are cattle on the road ahead?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. If you meet horses or other animals on the road, you should slow down and be prepared to stop. Don't use the horn or do anything that might frighten the animals. You must stop if directed to do so by the person in charge of animals.
questions: Sound the horn to try get the cattle to move aside.
The driver should reduce speed and overtake with care.
Switch on your headlights and try to pass as quickly as possible.
Sound the horn and overtake with care.
answer: The driver should reduce speed and overtake with care.

question: What should a driver do if they see horse riders on the road ahead?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. If you meet horses or other animals on the road, you should slow down and be prepared to stop. Don't use the horn or do anything that might frighten the animals. You must stop if directed to do so by the person in charge of animals.
questions: Maintain their speed while taking extra observation of the horses and how they are controlled by the riders.
The driver should reduce speed and allow extra clearance and pass with care.
Sound the horn and reduce their speed.
Turn on your hazard warning lights and continue at normal speed.
answer: The driver should reduce speed and allow extra clearance and pass with care.

question: What does these signs together mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign indicates the start of a cycle track. If the track is bounded by a broken white line, other road users should avoid using it wherever possible. If it is bounded by a continuous white line, drivers of cars and other vehicles must not drive on it.
questions: Bicycle race track.
Track reserved for motorcyclists.
Cyclists must dismount ahead.
Start of cycle track.
answer: Start of cycle track.

question: What should drivers be aware of if they meet horses with riders on the road?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You must know your responsibilities towards animal traffic on the road. Horses are easily startled and any sudden activity or noises could cause the to bolt.
questions: Drivers should be aware that loud noises from your vehicle may frighten the horses and cause them to bolt.
All horse riders are experienced at handling horses.
Any loud noise from your vehicle will not frighten the horses.
They may only pass in single file.
answer: Drivers should be aware that loud noises from your vehicle may frighten the horses and cause them to bolt.

question: What should the driver do when approaching a humpbacked hill?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: As you approach a humpbacked bridge or hill, you should be aware that there might be hidden dangers ahead-for example, overtaking traffic coming towards you. You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations such as this.
questions: The driver should reduce speed, keep to the left and be alert for hazards ahead.
Press the clutch pedal and sound the horn as a warning.
Maintain normal speed and road position.
Stop at the crest of the hill.
answer: The driver should reduce speed, keep to the left and be alert for hazards ahead.

question: What should a driver do if there is a large oil spill on the road?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: Where oil is spilt on the road, your tyres will have reduced grip, and you might be at risk if you break sharply. If you do come across oil in the road, brake gently and switch on your hazard warning lights for a short period to alert other traffic to the hazard.
questions: Maintain normal speeds in a lower gear and apply the hazard warning lights.
Depress the clutch and brake sharply and apply the hazard warning lights.
Try to straddle it with your wheels while maintaining normal speed.
Reduce speed by gently applying the brakes and switch on the hazard warning lights.
answer: Reduce speed by gently applying the brakes and switch on the hazard warning lights.

question: What do flashing amber beacons on an oncoming vehicle alert a driver to?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: Flashing amber beacons are used by recovery vehicles and vehicles carrying abnormal loads.You should be aware that these vehicles may need extra room and could conceal following traffic.When you come across such vehicles, slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions: That the oncoming traffic maybe slow moving or extra wide.
Is an emergency vehicle.
Is broken down.
Is fast moving.
answer: That the oncoming traffic maybe slow moving or extra wide.

question: What should a driver do if they meet a vehicle with flashing amber beacons?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: Flashing amber beacons are used by recovery vehicles and vehicles carrying abnormal loads.You should be aware that these vehicles may need extra room and could conceal following traffic.When you come across such vehicles, slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.
questions: That the oncoming vehicle is broken down.
That the oncoming vehicle is an emergency vehicle.
The oncoming vehicle is fast moving.
Slow down and be prepared to stop.
answer: Slow down and be prepared to stop.

question: What should a driver be aware of before crossing railway or tram lines?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You should be aware of the impact of changes in the roads surface. For example, at railway and tram crossings the uneven surface or oil deposits could reduce the grip of your tyres. Slow down as you approach railway or tram crossings and increase your distance from the vehicle in front.
questions: Tyre grip may be improved crossing the rails.
The wheels may become caught in the rails.
There may be an uneven surface and tyre grip may be reduced when crossing.
Oncoming trains.
answer: There may be an uneven surface and tyre grip may be reduced when crossing.

question: What should the driver be aware of when crossing road markings such as lines and directional arrows?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You should be aware of the impact of changes in the roads surface. For example, road markings and directional arrows can become slippery when wet. Where possible, avoid driving on road markings, and be aware of the increased risk of skidding.
questions: The stopping distance is reduced due to improved tyre grip.
The steering control is improved.
The stopping distance is increased due to reduced tyre grip.
The braking is improved.
answer: The stopping distance is increased due to reduced tyre grip.

question: There are pedestrians on the footpath ahead and there are pools of water on the road. What should a driver do?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: During wet conditions, you should be aware that surface water can affect the stability of your vehicle. This is particularly so where the water lies in pools. As you drive through surface water, you should show consideration to pedestrians and cyclists and try not to splash them as you pass.
questions: Sound the horn as a warning to the pedestrians and continue on.
Reduce speed and try to avoid the pools of water so as not to splash the pedestrians.
Flash the lights as a warning to the pedestrians.
Brake suddenly as you approach the pools of water.
answer: Reduce speed and try to avoid the pools of water so as not to splash the pedestrians.

question: When preparing to stop, a driver notices the vehicle behind is towing a trailer. What should the driver do?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: When you are slowing or stopping, you should be mindful of the type of vehicle that is following you. For example, if the vehicle following you is a large vehicle or one towing a trailer, you should think of indicating a little earlier than normal to allow the following vehicle enough time to react safely.
questions: Indicate in good time and pull up gradually to allow the vehicle behind extra stopping distance.
Use the hand brake to stop.
Speed up temporarily to put more distance between your vehicle and the vehicle behind you.
Stop quickly keeping a close eye on the rear-view mirror.
answer: Indicate in good time and pull up gradually to allow the vehicle behind extra stopping distance.

question: The bus ahead is moving away from a bus stop. What should a driver do?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: A driver should allow signalling buses back into the stream of traffic when they are moving out from a stop. Be careful of pedestrians getting on and off buses, particularly of children near schools.
questions: Drive alongside it because you have right-of-way.
Slow down and allow it to move out.
Try to get past it to avoid being delayed.
Signal to the bus driver to let you pass.
answer: Slow down and allow it to move out.

question: What must a driver do when this sign is NOT accompanied by a white stop line on the road?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: Where a STOP sign is not accompanied by a white stop line, you must stop at the sign.
questions: No more than one car length past the sign.
Stop at the sign.
Only if there is traffic at the junction.
Only when having passed the sign.
answer: Stop at the sign.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign indicates the start of a track for cyclists and pedestrians only. If the track is bounded by a broken white line, other road users should avoid using it wherever possible. If it is bounded by a continuous white line, drivers of cars and other vehicles must not drive on it.
questions: Parking area for cyclists ahead.
Area reserved for children learning to ride bicycles.
Shared cycle/pedestrian track.
Cyclists must dismount and walk.
answer: Shared cycle/pedestrian track.

question: What should a driver do on a narrow road when another vehicle is coming in the opposite direction?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You should always be prepared to react to hazards ahead.When you meet a vehicle coming against you on a narrow road,you should show consideration and slow down to an appropriate speed so that the two vehicles can pass each other safely.
questions: Maintain its position and expect the other vehicle to move over if necessary.
Reduce speed and allow reasonable clearance between their vehicle and the oncoming one before proceeding.
Expect the other driver to pull off the road.
Drive along the middle of the road to encourage other drives to pull in.
answer: Reduce speed and allow reasonable clearance between their vehicle and the oncoming one before proceeding.

question: When driving along and wishing to stop at a shop on the side of the street in order to make a purchase, what should a driver do?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You may park where it is safe and legal to do so. Your parked vehicle must not cause a danger or obstruction to other road users.
questions: Continue on to a safe parking space.
Switch on you hazard warning lights and park slightly up on the footpath.
Continue to a point where a 'U-turn' can be made safely and return to park on the footpath in the proper direction.
Park on the footpath so as not to impede the free flow of traffic on the road.
answer: Continue on to a safe parking space.

question: When a driver is driving behind another vehicle that they do not intend to overtake, what should the driver do?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You should always allow sufficient distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front. This will enable you to stop safely if necessary, and it will give overtaking vehicles enough room to pull in safely to the left lane after they have passed you.
questions: Keep well back and to the centre of the road.
Keep well back to allow following traffic to overtake them.
Drive close behind it in order to let following traffic overtake both vehicles.
Signal to following traffic to overtake both vehicles.
answer: Keep well back to allow following traffic to overtake them.

question: Why is tailgating (driving too close behind the vehicle in front) dangerous?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: If you close to the vehicle in front and it brakes suddenly,you will not have enough time ti react. For that reason you should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. One way of calculating the safe distance is the 'two-second rule': allow at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and your vehicle passing a fixed point such as a lamp post or sign post.
questions: The driver exceeds the speed limit when tailgating.
The drivers braking system is less efficient.
The driver prevents other vehicles from overtaking both vehicles safely.
The vehicle will not have sufficient distance to stop safely in an emergency.
answer: The vehicle will not have sufficient distance to stop safely in an emergency.

question: Is tailgating allowed on a motorway or dual carriageway?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: If you close to the vehicle in front and it brakes suddenly,you will not have enough time ti react. For that reason you should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. One way of calculating the safe distance is the 'two-second rule': allow at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and your vehicle passing a fixed point such as a lamp post or sign post.
questions: Yes, because there will be no oncoming traffic.
Only when all traffic moves in one direction at the same speed.
Yes, because traffic will not have to stop suddenly.
No, because the vehicle in front may stop suddenly.
answer: No, because the vehicle in front may stop suddenly.

question: What danger can arise during daylight when a driver enters an area that is heavily shaded by overhanging trees?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: When you enter a heavily shaded area after driving in bright sunlight, it might take a while for your eyes to adjust to the change, and you might not see a hazard immediatly ahead.
questions: The vehicle's engine could suddenly run cold.
Visibility could be suddenly reduced.
The vehicle's windscreen could fog up.
Falling branches.
answer: Visibility could be suddenly reduced.

question: What should a driver do when being overtaken by another vehicle?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: When you are being overtaking by another vehicle,you should continue at the same pace but be alert increase the overtaking vehicle suddenly pulls back in front you.
questions: Continue at the same pace.
Move to the right.
Move to the left.
Increase your speed.
answer: Continue at the same pace.

question: When should signals (for example, with indicators) be given to other road users?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: Giving signals is a way of telling other road users what you intend to do. So, you should signal properly before turning off,turning right or left, changing lanes, overtaking, slowing down or stopping. Signal clearly and in good time, and keep in mind that giving a signal does not give you the right of way.
questions: Only when it is necessary to warn following traffic.
Only when it is necessary to warn oncoming traffic.
Clearly and in good time to let other road users know your intentions.
Except where road markings indicate your direction.
answer: Clearly and in good time to let other road users know your intentions.

question: When driving into a narrow gap between oncoming vehicles and vehicles parked on the left. What should a driver do?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: When you meet approaching traffic at a narrow gap, you should show consideration and slow down to appropriate speed so that you and the other vehicles can pass by safely. If necessary give way to other vehicles.
questions: Edge your way forward around the parked vehicles.
Signal to oncoming traffic to halt and move to the right and drive as normal.
Indicate and drive on enforcing your priority.
Indicate right, stopping if necessary, until the oncoming traffic has passed by.
answer: Indicate right, stopping if necessary, until the oncoming traffic has passed by.

question: How does giving a late signal affect other road users?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: Giving signals is a way of telling other road users what you intend to do. So, you should signal properly before turning off,turning right or left, changing lanes, overtaking, slowing down or stopping. Signal clearly and in good time, and keep in mind that giving a signal does not give you the right of way. Late signals may confuse other road users.
questions: Only oncoming traffic are affected.
They may not have sufficient time to react.
They always have sufficient time in which to react.
They are not affected.
answer: They may not have sufficient time to react.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign is used by a school warden. When the warden raises this sign, you must stop and wait until the schoolchildren have crossed the road.
questions: Stop for school warden.
No access area for children.
Pedestrian crossing ahead.
No access. Pedestrianised street ahead.
answer: Stop for school warden.

question: How does rain affect driving in this situation?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: When it is wet, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as when it is dry, your stopping distance is increased and you are more likely to skid. For these reasons you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.
questions: It increases the danger of skidding.
It reduces your visibility.
It reduces the danger of skidding.
It increases the drivers visibility.
answer: It increases the danger of skidding.

question: When a driver is at a junction where visibility is extremely limited, what should the driver do?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: Where your view is obstructed at a junction, you should move carefully into a position where you can see, but without interfering with other road users. You should then assess the situation before you continue.
questions: Seek help from a passer-by.
Drive the front of the vehicle out onto the other road to enable other drivers to see you.
Sound the horn and quickly proceed.
Move out with extreme care, watching carefully to the left and the right.
answer: Move out with extreme care, watching carefully to the left and the right.

question: When should a driver use the vehicle’s rear view mirror?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: You should use your mirrors to stay aware of traffic behind and around you. Always check your mirror before you change direction on a road, and before you signal or begin a manoeuvre.
questions: Before changing direction
Changing gears.
Reversing only.
Moving off only.
answer: Before changing direction

question: How should a driver proceed if their view is obstructed at a junction?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: At junctions where the view is obstructed, move carefully into a position where you can see without interfering with other road users. Then assess the situation before you continue.
questions: Move out slowly onto the road while watching carefully for other traffic.
Flash lights on and off quickly before moving out.
Sound the horn several times and proceed.
Ask a passer-by to guide you out onto the other road.
answer: Move out slowly onto the road while watching carefully for other traffic.

question: What should a driver do when approaching traffic lights stuck on red?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: When you approach a junction with the traffic lights stuck on red, stop at the line, take the required observation and proceed with caution when it is safe to do so. Treat the junction as 'unmarked' and do not assume that you have the right of way.
questions: Sound your horn.
Check that there are no oncoming vehicles, and increase your speed.
Indicate and increase your speed.
Stop and proceed with great caution.
answer: Stop and proceed with great caution.

question: What should a driver do when there are dark clouds and visibility is reduced during daylight hours?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: Drivers need to see and be seen during all periods of low light level-for example, at dusk and dawn and in some bad weather conditions. At times of low light, you should turn on dipped headlights. The Road Safety Authority recommends that motorcyclists and drivers turn on their dipped headlights or daytime running lights during daylight hours.
questions: Drive with full headlights switched on.
Do not switch on lights until 'lighting-up hours'.
Drive with side-lights or dipped headlights switched on.
Keep close to any vehicle in front with headlights off.
answer: Drive with side-lights or dipped headlights switched on.

question: When driving behind a heavy goods vehicle that is signalling to turn right, what should a driver do?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: Heavy good veichles need extra space on the road, and when they are turning the overhang of the vehicle may swing out into the path of overtaking or passing traffic. For that reason,it is a good idea to stay back and let the heavy goods vehicle complete its turn unless there is sufficient space to overtake safely.
questions: Overtake it slowly on the inside by driving partly on the footpath if necessary.
Stay behind until there is sufficient space to overtake it on the inside or until it has completed the turn.
See if the vehicle can complete the turn without stopping, and if not, overtake it yourself.
Tap your brakes to signal other vehicles to slow down.
answer: Stay behind until there is sufficient space to overtake it on the inside or until it has completed the turn.

question: When driving behind a bus that is signalling to turn left and there is oncoming traffic, what should a driver do?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: Always allow a bus to complete a left hand turn - this is because your field of view might be restricted and it could be dangerous to attempt overtaking it.
questions: Overtake it on the left-hand side.
Overtake it on the right-hand side.
Tap your brakes to signal other vehicles to slow down.
Stay back and allow it to complete the turn.
answer: Stay back and allow it to complete the turn.

question: What might be described as a bus driver’s ‘blind spots’?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: A blind spot is an area a driver cannot see when looking forward or when looking in a mirrors.  The bigger the vehicle, the bigger the blind spots,and you should keep this in mind if you are driving behind a truck or a bus. If you are driving behind a truck and you cannot see the truck's mirror, then the truck driver cannot see you.
questions: The area to the front, sides and rear of the bus which the driver cannot see.
The windscreen area covered by the sun-visor.
The seats at the rear of the bus.
The sunscreens or blinds covering individual seats when pulled down.
answer: The area to the front, sides and rear of the bus which the driver cannot see.

question: Where are the blind spots on a truck  (for its driver) that a driver in a car behind the truck needs to be aware of?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: A blind spot is an area a driver cannot see when looking forward or when looking in a mirrors.  The bigger the vehicle, the bigger the blind spots,and you should keep this in mind if you are driving behind a truck or a bus. If you are driving behind a truck and you cannot see the truck's mirror, then the truck driver cannot see you.
questions: The area directly behind the vehicle.
The areas to the front, sides and rear which the driver cannot see.
The portion of the windscreen covered by the sun-visor.
Parts of the road ahead which are obscured by other large vehicles.
answer: The areas to the front, sides and rear which the driver cannot see.

question: What does these signs together mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign tells you there is a pedestrian area ahead and that traffic is not allowed except during the times stated on the information plate.
questions: Access for buses and taxis only during times shown.
Parking not allowed during times shown.
Pedestrianised street ahead - traffic not allowed except during times shown.
Roundabout ahead - no stopping or parking during times shown.
answer: Pedestrianised street ahead - traffic not allowed except during times shown.

question: Where are the blind spots that a driver needs to be aware of when towing a loaded trailer?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: A blind spot is an area a driver cannot see when looking forward or when looking in a mirrors. You should always check your blind spots before changing direction or changing lanes. The bigger the vehicle, the bigger the blind spots, and you should keep this in mind if you are driving behind a large vehicle, such as one towing a loaded trailer. In this situation, if you cannot see the towing vehicle's mirror, then the driver of that vehicle cannot see you.
questions: The view to the front hidden by the sun visor.
The number plate and lights on the rear of the vehicle and of the trailer.
The area directly behind the vehicle.
The areas to the side and rear of the vehicle and of the trailer that the driver cannot see.
answer: The areas to the side and rear of the vehicle and of the trailer that the driver cannot see.

question: When is it permissible to overtake another vehicle on the left-hand side?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: You may overtake on the left when the driver in the front has moved out and signalled their intent to turn right and you are going straight ahead-provide there is enough room to do so safely and your paths will not be obstructed by the swing of a large vehicle turning right.
questions: When there are three lanes available.
Never.
When the vehicle in front is signaling to turn right.
When there is sufficient space to do so.
answer: When the vehicle in front is signaling to turn right.

question: What should a driver who wishes to perform a U-turn do?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: If you want to do a U-turn you must first choose a place where it is safe and legal to do it. Check all around for other road users and do not impede their right of way. Complete the manoeuvre efficiently and safely.
questions: Check ahead and behind for approaching traffic.
Only perform a 'U'-turn outside the urban speed limit area.
Check behind for approaching traffic and signal them to stop.
Check ahead for approaching traffic and signal them to stop.
answer: Check ahead and behind for approaching traffic.

question: What should a driver who wishes to perform a turnabout do?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: If you want to do a turnabout, you must first choose a place where it is safe and legal to do so. Check all around for other road users and do not impede their right of way. Complete the manoeuvre efficiently and safely.
questions: Drive onto a footpath, is necessary, in order to ensure that you have sufficient room to turn.
Drive into somebody's driveway and reverse back onto the road.
Check ahead and behind for oncoming traffic and turn briskly while still keeping a look out.
Reverse into somebody's driveway and drive onto the road.
answer: Check ahead and behind for oncoming traffic and turn briskly while still keeping a look out.

question: What should drivers do if they become drowsy while driving?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Driving when you are tired can be very dangerous, and tiredness is one of the main causes of serious road collisions. Being very tired may cause you to micro-sleep (or nod off momentarily). At 100 km/h you travel at 28 metres a second, so if you micro sleep for just 4 seconds you would travel over 100 metres without being in control of the vehicle. If you become drowsy while driving, stop in a safe place and take a short nap. Then get some fresh air and stretch your legs for a few minutes before setting off again. Taking a caffeine-based drink such as coffee may also help.
questions: Open a window or turn on the air conditioning to let cool air into the vehicle.
Stop, take a break including a short walk if possible.
Stretch your arms and close your eyes for short periods.
Turn up the heating.
answer: Stop, take a break including a short walk if possible.

question: What should the driver do if they are driving and feel tired?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Driving when you are tired can be very dangerous, and tiredness is one of the main causes of serious road collisions. Being very tired may cause you to micro-sleep (or nod off momentarily). At 100 km/h you travel at 28 metres a second, so if you micro sleep for just 4 seconds you would travel over 100 metres without being in control of the vehicle. Never drive if you are fighting sleep.
questions: The driver should stop and take a break.
The driver should drive along the centre of the road.
The driver should increase speed to shorten the journey time.
The driver should eat something.
answer: The driver should stop and take a break.

question: What should a driver do if they are behind schedule in reaching a destination at an appointed time?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: You should always drive at a speed that allows you to stop safely within the distance you can see to be clear. Being late for an appointment is no excuse for exceeding speed limits or for driving at an unsafe speed. Arrive alive.
questions: Be patient and drive so as to arrive safely.
Exceed the speed limit, if necessary, to make up the time.
Drive on the hard shoulder where available.
Drive aggressively.
answer: Be patient and drive so as to arrive safely.

question: What should a driver do if they do not want to travel as fast as the vehicle in front?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situation. You should not drive so slowly that your vehicle unnecessarily blocks other road users. If you want to allow the vehicle behind to overtake, you may pull into the hard shoulder briefly as long as no pedestrians or cyclists are using it and there are no junctions or entrances nearby.
questions: The driver should keep to the left and allow vehicles to overtake if they wish.
The driver should keep its position and allow following vehicles to overtake if they wish.
The driver should give a hand signal to following traffic to overtake.
The driver should indicate left and keep to the left.
answer: The driver should keep to the left and allow vehicles to overtake if they wish.

question: What should a driver do if they wish to drive across a busy road and the traffic lights which normally control the junction are temporarily out of action?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Always read the road ahead to react to any traffic situation. In this case,do not proceed until it is clear and safe to do so. Do not assume that you have the right of way.
questions: Sound the horn and proceed slowly to cross the road.
Slowly force you way across, using hazard warning lights if necessary.
Take good observations, wait for a clear break in the traffic and proceed to cross the road.
Beckon to other drivers your intention to cross, and proceed.
answer: Take good observations, wait for a clear break in the traffic and proceed to cross the road.

question: What should a driver do if they see a school bus stopped on the left-hand side of the road ahead?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Always read the road and be prepared to react to any traffic situation-in this case,be aware of vulnerable road users such as school children boarding or alighting from school buses.
questions: Reduce speed and overtake with caution.
Sound the horn as a warning and continue.
Carry on regardless.
Signal and maintain current speed.
answer: Reduce speed and overtake with caution.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign tells you that you must not enter this area if your vehicle is over the stated weight limit.
questions: Minimum permitted weight is 3 tonnes.
Maximum permitted weight is 3 tonnes.
3 axled vehicles not permitted.
Only 3 axled vehicles are permitted.
answer: Maximum permitted weight is 3 tonnes.

question: What should the driver do when driving behind a vehicle that is going from side to side on the road in an unsafe manner?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Always read the road and be prepared to react to hazards ahead. If the vehicle in front is moving from side to side, it may indicate that the driver is not paying full attention or that their driving is impaired by drink, drugs or tiredness. Overtake such a vehicle only if you are sure it is safe to do so. If you think the vehicle is a risk to the public safety, you should report it to the Gardaí or to traffic watch lo-call 1890 205 805.
questions: The driver should stay well back until the road widens sufficiently to allow safe overtaking.
The driver should signal and go around to the left of the vehicle.
The driver should flash its lights and gesture aggressively at the other driver.
The driver should drive close behind with a view to overtaking.
answer: The driver should stay well back until the road widens sufficiently to allow safe overtaking.

question: What should a driver do if a heavy goods vehicle in front has moved out to make a left turn ahead?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situations. In this case,you should be aware that the heavy goods vehicle will need extra space to complete the left-hand turn and you should remain behind the vehicle until it has completed its turn.
questions: Stay behind it and allow it to finish the turn.
Drive into the space on its left-hand side.
Move to the right, but do not overtake.
Move out immediately and overtake as quickly as possible.
answer: Stay behind it and allow it to finish the turn.

question: What should a driver do if a bus in front has moved out to make a left-hand turn and there is oncoming traffic?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situations. In this case,you should be aware that the heavy goods vehicle will need extra space to make the turn. So you should not overtake it if by doing so you would cause oncoming traffic to alter speed or course. Remember, you should never overtake when approaching a junction.
questions: Maintain your speed until you are close behind the bus.
Overtake on the left hand-side.
Stay back and allow the bus to complete the turn.
Overtake on the right hand-side.
answer: Stay back and allow the bus to complete the turn.

question: What should a driver do if they see a truck reversing into a side entrance on the left-hand side of the road ahead?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any traffic situations. You should be aware of the difficulties of drivers of large vehicles can have reversing into a side entrance. In this case a large vehicle reversing could obstruct your view of the road ahead as you approach, and you should proceed only if you are sure the way ahead is clear.
questions: Try to drive past it.
Drive up close to the truck and stop.
Sound your horn to indicate to the driver of the truck that you wish to overtake.
Stop and wait until your way is clear.
answer: Stop and wait until your way is clear.

question: What should a driver do if they wish to turn right at traffic lights while the green light is showing and there is oncoming traffic approaching?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: If you wish to turn right at a set of traffic lights, drive into the junction where you see a green light, taking care not to block oncoming traffic. Then complete the turn when it is safe to do so.
questions: Remain at the stop line until a suitable gap in the oncoming traffic appears before making the turn.
Wait until a green arrow comes on.
Go forward towards the centre of the junction and wait for a suitable gap to appear in the oncoming traffic before making the turn.
Wait for the light to turn amber and then make the turn.
answer: Go forward towards the centre of the junction and wait for a suitable gap to appear in the oncoming traffic before making the turn.

question: When is it permitted to force oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder on the opposite side of the road while overtaking?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Overtaking in the manner described here is dangerous. You should overtake another vehicle only when it is safe to do so, both for you and for all other traffic. Before you overtake, make sure the road ahead is clear and that you have enough room to complete the overtaking manoeuvre and return to your side of the road without forcing any other road user to alter speed course.
questions: When the vehicle you are overtaking moves over and slows down.
It is not permitted to force oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder while overtaking.
When none of the oncoming traffic is overtaking.
When the shoulder is wide enough.
answer: It is not permitted to force oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder while overtaking.

question: Forcing oncoming traffic onto the hard shoulder on the opposite side of the road - is this safe driving?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Overtaking in the manner described here is dangerous. You should overtake another vehicle only when it is safe to do so, both for you and for all other traffic. Before you overtake, make sure the road ahead is clear and that you have enough room to complete the overtaking manoeuvre and return to your side of the road without forcing any other road user to alter speed course.
questions: Dangerous driving only at night.
Only acceptable when the oncoming traffic is slow moving.
No, this is dangerous driving.
Yes, this is safe driving.
answer: No, this is dangerous driving.

question: When meeting oncoming traffic on a national road, is it permitted to move into the hard shoulder to allow following traffic to overtake?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: On national roads, the hard shoulder is normally for the use of pedestrians and cyclists only. If you want to allow a vehicle behind to overtake, you may pull into the hard shoulder briefly as long as no pedestrians or cyclists are using it and there are no junctions or entrances nearby. In the case of motorways, however, you must not drive on the hard shoulder, except in an emergency.
questions: Never.
Yes, temporarily when the hard shoulder is clear, and it is safe to drive there while the faster traffic overtakes.
Yes, when a truck or bus is oncoming.
Yes, when there is a junction up ahead on the left.
answer: Yes, temporarily when the hard shoulder is clear, and it is safe to drive there while the faster traffic overtakes.

question: When driving on a national road is it permitted to drive on the hard shoulder in order to allow faster-moving traffic to overtake?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: On national roads, the hard shoulder is normally for the use of pedestrians and cyclists only. If you want to allow a vehicle behind to overtake, you may pull into the hard shoulder briefly as long as no pedestrians or cyclists are using it and there are no junctions or entrances nearby. In the case of motorways, however, you must not drive on the hard shoulder, except in an emergency.
questions: Only when driving on a dual-carriageway.
Never.
Yes, temporarily, when the shoulder is clear, and it is safe to drive there while the traffic overtakes you.
Only when a truck or bus wishes to overtake you.
answer: Yes, temporarily, when the shoulder is clear, and it is safe to drive there while the traffic overtakes you.

question: What action should a driver take in a queue of traffic controlled by traffic lights?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to any situation. From time to time you may have to queue in traffic. In this situation, you should try to remain patient and considerate of other road users. Jumping the queue is inconsiderate, it could be dangerous, and could even provoke road rage incident or cause a collision.
questions: A driver should always maintain their position in the queue.
A driver should overtake on the right and move to the head of the queue.
A driver should watch only for any vehicle overtaking on the right side.
A driver should overtake on the left and move to the head of the queue.
answer: A driver should always maintain their position in the queue.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign tells you that you must not enter this area if your vehicle is over the stated weight limit. This may be found at a weak bridge. There are no exemptions.
questions: Vehicles weight restriction is 10 tonnes.
Vehicles weighing more than 10 tonnes per axle not permitted.
Minimum permitted weight is 10 tonnes.
Vehicles exceeding 10 meters in length are not permitted.
answer: Vehicles weight restriction is 10 tonnes.

question: What should the driver do when driving a vehicle they are not familiar with?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: You should know where to find and how to operate all the controls on your vehicle, including all of its safety features and warning lamps. When you are driving, you need to be able to concentrate on what's happening around you and operating the vehicle controls should be second nature to you. When you sit into the driver's seat of a vehicle you are not familiar with, you should do a thorough 'cockpit drill' before you move off.
questions: Avoid any long journeys until you are more familiar with the vehicle.
Drive initially with extra care and at a lower speed than normal.
Drive at your normal speed and become accustomed to its features over time.
Drive faster than normal in order to assess its capability.
answer: Drive initially with extra care and at a lower speed than normal.

question: What should drivers do if they approach road works and there is earth-moving machinery moving about?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: When earth-moving machinery is working, there are likely to be mud and gravel deposits on the road. Also the noise of such machines might make it hard for road workers to hear the approaching traffic. When you come across earth-moving machinery, slow down and proceed with extreme caution.
questions: Reduce speed as there maybe loose gravel or mud on the road.
Engage a lower gear.
Be aware that the road surface may be uneven.
Be aware that there may be loose gravel on the road.
answer: Reduce speed as there maybe loose gravel or mud on the road.

question: Subject to the speed limit, what is the ‘safest’ speed to drive at?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: You should always drive at a speed that allows you to stop within the distance ahead that you can see to be clear. If you don't think you could safety bring the vehicle to a stop within the range of what you can see, then you're driving too fast - slow down.
questions: The speed that will enable the driver to stop the vehicle within the distance ahead that they can see to be clear.
The speed of other road users.
At the speed limit.
The speed of the slowest vehicle on the road.
answer: The speed that will enable the driver to stop the vehicle within the distance ahead that they can see to be clear.

question: When driving along and wishing to use a hand-held mobile phone, what should a driver do?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: It is an offence and very unsafe to use a hand-held mobile phone while driving a vehicle or riding a motorbike. It is unsafe because it prevents you from concentrating fully on your driving. Using a hands-free phone kit is not illegal, but in some circumstances it could be a dangerous distraction, and you could be prosecuted for dangerous driving, careless driving without due care and attention.
questions: Move the phone as needed and keep the call to just a few minutes.
Steer with one hand.
Secure the phone between your shoulder and the side or your head while steering with both hands.
Stop at a safe location before using the phone.
answer: Stop at a safe location before using the phone.

question: When stopped at traffic lights and the green light comes on, what should a driver do?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: When stopped at traffic lights and the green light comes on, you should check to ensure the way is clear and proceed only if it is safe to do so.
questions: Accelerate at the same rate as other drivers.
Check that other road users have cleared the junction and move off with care.
Accelerate quickly so as not to delay the traffic.
Check your mirrors and move off quickly.
answer: Check that other road users have cleared the junction and move off with care.

question: What should a driver do if another vehicle blocks their right of way at a junction?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: You should always try to show restraint. It is important to understand that the right of way is not an absolute right of way. and you must always proceed with caution and with regard for other road users.
questions: Be patient.
Flash your lights to express your displeasure.
Go after the vehicle with the intention of complaining to the driver.
Sound your horn.
answer: Be patient.

question: A driver who is about to undertake a journey is upset or angry. What should they do?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: If you drive when you are angry or upset, you are more likely to be involved in a collision, and more likely to react to other drivers' bad behaviour. Take the time to calm down and compose yourself before you set out on a journey.
questions: Not drive until they are calm.
Only drive in a low gear for a period.
Try to relax as they drive along.
Drive slower than normal for a distance.
answer: Not drive until they are calm.

question: When being overtaken and there is oncoming traffic, what should a driver do?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: When you are been overtaking and there are oncoming vehicles, you should show consideration for all other traffic and slow down to allow the overtaking vehicle to move in front of you to avoid the risk of a collision.
questions: Maintain your position because the other driver should not have attempted to overtake you.
Maintain your position and flash your lights to warn the oncoming traffic.
Speed up so they cannot overtake you.
Reduce speed and allow the overtaking vehicle to return to the left side of the road after completing the overtaking manoeuvre.
answer: Reduce speed and allow the overtaking vehicle to return to the left side of the road after completing the overtaking manoeuvre.

question: When in a hurry and another vehicle cuts in front, what should a driver do?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: If another driver behaves badly, you should try not let it annoy you — show restraint and don't react. Road rage only increases the risk of a collision.
questions: Be patient and not retaliate.
Flash your lights to express your annoyance.
Pull up closely behind them so that the other vehicles cannot cut into your path.
Drive faster to make up for lost time.
answer: Be patient and not retaliate.

question: What should a driver do when they get a puncture while driving?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: If you get a puncture while driving, find a suitable and safe place to stop and change the wheel. If you can't find a suitable place immediately, drive slowly (with your hazard warning lights turned on) to avoid further damage to the tyre or rim until a safe place is found.
questions: Stop immediately, unless on a motorway and change the tyre.
Stop immediately and change the tyre.
Drive to the closest repair shop and have them change the tyre.
Stop at a safe place and change the tyre.
answer: Stop at a safe place and change the tyre.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This signs tells you that heavy goods vehicles with five or more axles are not permitted to enter this road.
questions: No entry to goods vehicles with five axles or more.
Racing track ahead.
Minimum permitted weight is 5 tonnes.
Car transporter unloading area.
answer: No entry to goods vehicles with five axles or more.

question: What should a driver do when they want to change to the lane on the right in which there is other traffic?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Any time you change lanes, you should use the Mirror—Signal—Mirror (blind spots)—Manoeuvre routine. Check your mirrors, signal your intention, check your mirrors again (and your blind spots), and when a suitable gap becomes available manoeuvre the vehicle into the next lane, giving way to traffic already in that lane.
questions: Pull in and stop, wait until a suitable gap appears and then move out to the right-hand lane.
Use the mirror, signal and move into the right-hand lane when a suitable gap appears in the traffic in that lane.
Indicate and move gradually into the right-hand lane.
Increase your speed until you are travelling at the same speed as the traffic in the right lane, then move over.
answer: Use the mirror, signal and move into the right-hand lane when a suitable gap appears in the traffic in that lane.

question: What effect does drinking alcohol have on a driver?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Alcohol is a major factor in collisions that lead to death and injury. Even small amounts of alcohol affect your judgement, your concentration and your ability to react to hazards. A driver should never ever drink and drive.
questions: It improves co-ordination.
It increases awareness.
It makes the driver drowsy.
It increases your concentration.
answer: It makes the driver drowsy.

question: If a motorist or a motorcyclist is taking medication which may affect their driving, what should they do?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Some medication can affect a drivers ability to drive safely. If you are on medication of any kind, you should ask your doctor or pharmacist to tell you if it is safe to drive while taking it. Read the patient information leaflet supplied with the medication.
questions: Drive for short distances only.
Seek medical advice in relation to driving.
Driving plenty of water while driving.
Make sure that the medication is recorded on your licence record.
answer: Seek medical advice in relation to driving.

question: If taking unprescribed medication what should a driver check before driving their vehicle?
heading: Good Judgement and Perception
explanation: Explantion: Some medication can affect a drivers ability to drive safely. If you are on medication of any kind, you should ask your doctor or pharmacist to tell you if it is safe to drive while taking it. Read the patient information leaflet supplied with the medication.
questions: Check that the medication does not affect driving.
Only medication issued under prescription may cause drowsiness.
Use of soft drugs prior to driving will not affect your driving.
Use of soft drugs would never cause you to take risks while driving.
answer: Check that the medication does not affect driving.

question: What effect does a wet road surface have on a vehicle’s braking ability?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: When it is wet, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as when it is dry and your stopping distance is increased. For these reasons you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.
questions: It decreases the braking distance for vehicles without ABS.
It reduces the braking distance required.
Generally. it doubles the normal braking distance required on a dry surface.
It makes no difference to the braking distance.
answer: Generally. it doubles the normal braking distance required on a dry surface.

question: When driving uphill behind a slow-moving vehicle, what should a driver do?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: Overtake only if your view of the road ahead is completely clear, there is no oncoming traffic and you can complete the manoeuvre safely. Do not overtake when you are approaching the brow of a hill where you cannot see if there is oncoming traffic.
questions: Drive close behind it while keeping to the centre or the road.
Drive alongside of it until you can overtake it.
Drive close behind it while keeping well to the left.
Stay well behind the vehicle until it can be overtaken safely .
answer: Stay well behind the vehicle until it can be overtaken safely .

question: After overtaking another vehicle, what should a driver do?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: After overtaking, check your mirrors, signal and return to your normal lane position as soon as it is safe. Take a smooth easy line and don't cut in sharply.
questions: Gradually move back into the left when the vehicle has been overtaken.
Cut back in front of the vehicle and reduce speed.
Continue to signal right for a distance.
Cut into the left as soon as they have passed it.
answer: Gradually move back into the left when the vehicle has been overtaken.

question: What could happen if a driver cuts in too soon when overtaking another vehicle?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: You should always ensure that you are safely past the vehicle you are overtaking before resuming normal lane position. Cutting in too soon could lead to a collision.
questions: Your engine could increase power.
Your engine could lose power.
The steering could lock.
Both vehicles could collide.
answer: Both vehicles could collide.

question: What should a driver do when overtaking parked vehicles?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: When you are passing a parked vehicle, move into the correct position in good time and leave plenty of clearance room between your vehicle and the parked vehicle — just in case someone opens the door in front of you.
questions: Watch in their right-hand mirror.
Move as far to the right as possible.
Allow sufficient clearance when passing.
Keep close to the vehicles and watch out for pedestrians.
answer: Allow sufficient clearance when passing.

question: What stopping distance should a driver allow when they suspect that the road might be icy?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: When driving in snow or icy conditions a driver should allow a greater distance from the vehicle in front as stopping distances can be increased by up to ten times the normal.
questions: Up to ten times the normal distance.
Twice the normal distance.
The normal distance.
Up to half the normal.
answer: Up to ten times the normal distance.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign tells you that you must not enter this area if your vehicle exceeds the indicated height.
questions: Maximum permitted height of vehicle is figure indicated.
Maximum permitted length of vehicle is figure indicated.
Vehicles exceeding length measurements must have reflective strips.
Maximum permitted weight of vehicle is figure indicated.
answer: Maximum permitted height of vehicle is figure indicated.

question: What clearance should drivers normally allow for parked vehicles?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: When you are passing a parked vehicle, move into the correct position in good time and leave plenty of clearance room between your vehicle and the parked vehicle — just in case someone opens the door in front of you.
questions: The width or an average person.
A door width.
Six meters.
The width of the mirror.
answer: A door width.

question: Why does it take longer to stop the vehicle on a wet road?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: When it is wet, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as when it is dry and your stopping distance is increased. For these reasons you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.
questions: The suspension of the vehicle is lighter in wet weather.
The tyres have more grip than in dry weather.
The tyres have less road grip than in dry weather.
The brake fluid is less effective in wet weather.
answer: The tyres have less road grip than in dry weather.

question: What is the effect on driving if there is a film of water between the vehicle’s tyres and the road surface?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: On a wet road, a film of water can build up between the tyres and the road surface. This is called 'aquaplaning and it has the effect of reducing the grip of the tyres on the road.
questions: Steering and braking will be more effective.
Steering and braking will be less effective.
Braking only will be less effective.
Steering will be more effective.
answer: Steering and braking will be less effective.

question: What should a driver do if they encounter loose chippings on a road?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: Where there are loose chippings on the road, you should slow down and leave extra room (or clearance) between your vehicle and other traffic. This will also give you more time to stop if you need to. and it will help to reduce the amount of chippings your vehicle throws up against other vehicles.
questions: Stop the vehicle until the loose chippings can be removed.
Increase speed so as to avoid causing damage to the vehicle.
Press their hand against the windscreen or motorcycle faring.
Slow down and allow extra clearance to all traffic until they have gone past the area with the loose chippings.
answer: Slow down and allow extra clearance to all traffic until they have gone past the area with the loose chippings.

question: What effect does spilt diesel have on a road?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: Diesel spilt on the road can make the road surface extremely slippery, particularly if the road is wet.
questions: It makes the road more slippery.
It improves the vehicles braking ability.
Improve tyre grip on bends.
It increases tyre noise.
answer: It makes the road more slippery.

question: What should a driver do when driving in slippery road conditions?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: When driving in slippery road conditions, you should be particularly smooth and gradual in the way you accelerate and brake. This will help you avoid skidding or slipping.
questions: Drive at faster speeds to maintain tyre grip.
Drive at lower speeds and use gentle acceleration and braking.
Apply the brakes sharply from time to time to test the road surface.
Drive at normal speed but allow extra stopping distance.
answer: Drive at lower speeds and use gentle acceleration and braking.

question: What should a driver do when travelling downhill on snow or ice?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: When travelling downhill in snow or ice, you should select a lower gear to take advantage of engine braking and use the brakes very gently when you need to.
questions: Keep close to the left and brake sharply to keep the speed down.
Use a higher gear than normal in order to avoid wheel spin.
Avoid using the brake and use a high gear.
Use an appropriate lower gear and brake gently to reduce speed.
answer: Use an appropriate lower gear and brake gently to reduce speed.

question: How does driving at high speed affect a vehicle’s road holding?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: Driving at high speed is a factor that affects road holding. At higher speeds the airflow under a vehicle reduces tyre grip on the road and when you are approaching a bend or corner, the momentum of the vehicle makes it more difficult to change direction.
questions: The road holding ability of the vehicle is increased.
The wheel alignment keeps the tyres in full contact with the road.
The road holding ability of the vehicle is reduced.
The suspension compensates for any unevenness in the road surface.
answer: The road holding ability of the vehicle is reduced.

question: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 50 km/h on a dry road?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: Normal stopping distance is the distance you travel while you react to a situation plus the distance you travel while you are bringing the vehicle to a stop.
questions: 15 metres.
25 metres.
45 metres.
5 metres.
answer: 25 metres.

question: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 50 km/h on a wet road?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
explanation: Explantion: Normal stopping distance is the distance you travel while you react to a situation plus the distance you travel while you are bringing the vehicle to a stop. On a wet road, it will take longer to bring the vehicle to a stop, as the tyres do not grip the road as well in the wet.
questions: 36 metres.
46 metres.
16 metres.
26 metres.
answer: 36 metres.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign tells you that you must not park in this area if your vehicle is over the weight limit indicated.
questions: Parking of vehicles exceeding the weight shown is not allowed.
Passing other traffic that exceeds the weight shown is prohibited.
Parking of vehicles under the weight shown is not allowed.
Parking in loading area is not allowed.
answer: Parking of vehicles exceeding the weight shown is not allowed.

question: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 100 km/h on a dry road?
heading: Observance of Safe Distance
