explanation: Explantion: Before leaving your vehicle, apply the handbrake, switch off the engine and engage low engage a low gear. If the vehicles if fitted with automatic transmission, select 'P' (park).
questions: Angle the wheels away from the kerb and stop the engine.
Engage a low gear and stop the engine.
Angle the wheels towards the kerb and stop the engine.
Apply the parking brake, stop the engine and engage a low gear.
answer: Apply the parking brake, stop the engine and engage a low gear.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign gives advance warning of an automatic level crossing ahead. Prepare to stop.
questions: Automatic level crossing ahead.
Bridge may be raised ahead.
Pelican crossing ahead.
Traffic lights may be activated by passing traffic.
answer: Automatic level crossing ahead.

question: What precaution should a driver take when getting out of their vehicle?
heading: Environmental Matters
explanation: Explantion: Before opening any door, check for other road users passing, and in particular look out for pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists. Exit the vehicle only when it is safe to do so, and close the door as soon as possible. Passengers should exit on the side nearest  the kerb wherever possible.
questions: Ensure the gear lever is in neutral.
Ensure all valuables are secure and out of sight.
Open the door and try to get out as speedily as possible.
Check all around for approaching traffic and pedestrians before opening the door.
answer: Check all around for approaching traffic and pedestrians before opening the door.

question: On a busy road, how should a driver allow passengers out of a vehicle?
heading: Environmental Matters
explanation: Explantion: Before allowing any door to be opened, check for other road users passing, and in particular look out for pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists. Passengers should exit on the side nearest the kerb, without getting in the way of pedestrians.
questions: Stop and allow them to get out on the side nearest the kerb.
Stop and allow them to get out from whichever side of the vehicle they are sitting.
Stop and ask them to get out as quickly as possible.
Signal to following traffic to overtake before allowing the passengers to get out.
answer: Stop and allow them to get out on the side nearest the kerb.

question: What cars are required to have rear seat belts fitted?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: Rear seat belts are compulsory on all cars registered after 1st January 1992.
questions: Cars first registered prior to 1st January 1992.
All cars.
Cars first registered after 1st January 1992.
Cars first registered prior to 1st January 1995.
answer: Cars first registered after 1st January 1992.

question: Where seat belts are fitted to a car when must adult occupants wear them?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: The driver and all passengers in a car must wear a seatbelt or, in the case of a child, a suitable restraint system.
questions: For all journeys exceeding 10 kilometers.
On long journeys only.
At all times.
Except in built-up areas.
answer: At all times.

question: What is the purpose of a seatbelt?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: Seatbelts save lives and reduce the risk of injury by restraining the occupants of a vehicle in the event of a crash or sudden deceleration.
questions: To prevent the wearer from being thrown backwards in the event of an crash.
To keep the seat upright in the event of an crash.
To prevent the wearer from being thrown forward in the event of a crash or abrupt deceleration.
To prevent the seat from moving forward when the brakes are applied.
answer: To prevent the wearer from being thrown forward in the event of a crash or abrupt deceleration.

question: When should a driver put on their safety belt?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: Before moving off, put on your seatbelt and make sure that all your passengers also have theirs on.
questions: Not later than the time they engage top gear.
When driving outside an urban area.
Once their speed has exceeded 50 km/h.
Before they move off.
answer: Before they move off.

question: Who is responsible for ensuring that a passenger over 17 years of age is wearing a seat belt while travelling in a car?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: If the passenger is over the age of 17. it is their responsibility to comply with the seat belt regulations. Below that age, it is the drivers responsibility.
questions: The driver when the passenger is in the front seat.
The passengers only.
The driver only.
Both the driver and the passengers.
answer: The passengers only.

question: Who is responsible for ensuring that a passenger under 17 years of age is wearing a seat belt while travelling in a car?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: If the passenger is over the age of 17, it is their responsibility to comply with the seat belt regulations. Below that age, it is the drivers responsibility.
questions: The passengers' parents.
The passengers themselves.
The driver.
The driver, when the passenger is in the front seat.
answer: The driver.

question: In general, how should infants be secured in a vehicle?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: As safety belts are designed mainly for adults and older children, infants and small children must be restrained in an appropriate child restraint system.
questions: They should always be secured in a child restraint system.
They should always be placed in the front passenger seat.
They should always be placed in the front passenger seat wearing a seat-belt.
They should always be carried on an adults lap.
answer: They should always be secured in a child restraint system.

question: Should an infant who is not secured in a child restraint system be carried in the front passenger seat?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: Infants and small children must be restrained in an appropriate child restraint system.
questions: Yes.
No, an infant must always be restrained in a correct child seat.
Yes, only if the vehicle is fitted with airbags.
Yes if held by an adult.
answer: No, an infant must always be restrained in a correct child seat.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign gives advance warning of a hump in the road. You should adjust your speed accordingly.
questions: Series of bumps or hollows ahead.
Road falls from center to left and right.
Road reflective studs ahead.
Sharp rise in the road ahead - for example, a hump-back bridge.
answer: Sharp rise in the road ahead - for example, a hump-back bridge.

question: How should a child restraint system be secured in a vehicle?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: A child restraint system should be secured in the vehicle either with the seatbelts of the car or with approved fixings. Always use a restraint system that is appropriate for the age, height and weight of the child, and follow the manufacturers instr
questions: It should be placed on a normal passenger seat.
It should be placed on the floor.
It should be secured with seat belts or ISOFIX fittings.
It should be left unsecured.
answer: It should be secured with seat belts or ISOFIX fittings.

question: What should a driver do when driving a vehicle with young children as passengers?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: If the passenger is over the age of 17. it is their responsibility to comply with the seatbelt regulations. Below that age. it is the drivers responsibility.
questions: Make certain that an older passenger is sitting next to them.
Make sure each child is wearing a seat belt or using an appropriate restraint system.
Check in your rear-view mirror to ensure the children seated in the back seat are safe.
Make sure the eldest children are seated in the back seat.
answer: Make sure each child is wearing a seat belt or using an appropriate restraint system.

question: What is the purpose of side-impact protection bars?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: Side-impact protection bars are fitted to some vehicles to protect the occupants of the vehicle in the event of a collision from the side.
questions: To protect the doors from becoming damaged in the event of a crash.
To make sure that the vehicle cannot be overturned when hit from the side.
To increase the weight of the vehicle thereby improving its grip on the road.
To protect the occupants when the vehicle is hit from the side.
answer: To protect the occupants when the vehicle is hit from the side.

question: What should a driver do if a tyre bursts on the vehicle they are driving?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: If a tyre bursts on your vehicle, keep a firm hold of the steering, slow down gradually and stop where it is safe to do so. Switch on the hazard warning lights.
questions: Hold the steering wheel firmly and pull in on the side of the road.
Pull on the handbrake.
Brake as quickly as possible.
Continue on at a normal speed.
answer: Hold the steering wheel firmly and pull in on the side of the road.

question: How should a driver use the brakes if the vehicle is fitted with anti-lock brakes (ABS)?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: If your vehicle is fitted with ABS. brake firmly. ABS will not stop the vehicle more quickly, it will only prevent the wheels from locking. This helps you to maintain control of the vehicle.
questions: Press the brake-pedal only lightly.
Press and release the brake at slow intervals.
Press and release the brake at rapid intervals.
Press the brake pedal firmly and hold.
answer: Press the brake pedal firmly and hold.

question: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a front-wheel sideways skid?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: If your vehicle goes into a front-wheel sideways skid, release the accelerator and do not try to steer until the tyres regain some grip on the road.
questions: Release the accelerator.
Press the footbrake.
Continue to accelerate.
Apply the handbrake.
answer: Release the accelerator.

question: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a four-wheel sideways skid?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: If your vehicle goes into a four-wheel skid, turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and ease off the accelerator. This should help to bring the wheels back into line and allow you to regain control.
questions: Push in the clutch and apply the handbrake to bring the car to a halt.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and ease off the accelerator.
Apply the footbrake strongly.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction and apply the handbrake to bring the car to a halt.
answer: Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and ease off the accelerator.

question: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a rear-wheel sideways skid?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: If your vehicle goes into a rear-wheel sideways skid, turn the steering in the direction the rear wheels are heading. This should be done very gradually, as too much steering could cause the vehicle to skid in the opposite direction.
questions: Apply the footbrake strongly to bring the car to a halt.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the rear wheels are heading.
Turn the steering wheel in the opposite direction in which the front wheels are heading.
Turn the steering wheel in the same direction in which the front wheels are heading.
answer: Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the rear wheels are heading.

question: How should a driver in a vehicle without anti-lock brakes (ABS) deal with a front-wheel straight-line skid?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: If your vehicle does not have ABS and it goes into a straight-line front-wheel skid due to braking. press and release the brake pedal repeatedly and rapidly. This will help to restore tyre grip and enable you to regain control.
questions: Turn the steering gently left or right.
Push in the clutch and take your foot off the accelerator.
Apply the footbrake strongly.
Press and release the footbrake at rapid intervals.
answer: Press and release the footbrake at rapid intervals.

question: What should a driver do if they get a tyre blow-out on the road?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: If a tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, slow down gradually and find a safe and suitable place to stop. Switch on your hazard warning lights and change the wheel or call for assistance.
questions: Switch off the engine ignition to help bring the vehicle to a halt.
Apply the handbrake immediately to help bring the vehicle to a halt.
Apply the footbrake gently and bring the vehicle to a halt.
Apply the footbrake firmly.
answer: Apply the footbrake gently and bring the vehicle to a halt.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign tells you that you must turn right, its usually displayed at a junction where all traffic must turn right - for example, in a one way system that incorporates a junction.
questions: Overtake only on the right
Diversion ahead to the right.
Turn right only.
Major road joining from the left.
answer: Turn right only.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign gives advance warning of a dip or depression in the road ahead. You should reduce your speed accordingly.
questions: Road divides ahead - pass left or right.
Road damage ahead.
Low bridge ahead.
Sharp depression or dip ahead.
answer: Sharp depression or dip ahead.

question: What effect could a front-tyre blow-out have on a vehicle?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: If a front tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, you will feel the effect of it through the steering wheel. The wheel will generally pull to the side of the blown-out tyre.
questions: The vehicle to pull to the rear away from the front blow-out.
The steering wheel will pull to one side.
The wheels to lock.
The vehicle will become easier to control.
answer: The steering wheel will pull to one side.

question: What effect could a rear-tyre blow-out have on a vehicle?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: If a rear tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out the vehicle may sway from side to side, and this will affect its stability. Slow down, pull in where it is safe to do so. and switch on the hazard warning lights. Change the wheel or call for assistance.
questions: It could cause the vehicle wheels to lock.
It could cause the vehicle to sway from side to side.
It could cause the vehicle to pull towards the side with the blow-out.
It could cause the vehicle to pull away from the side with the blow-out.
answer: It could cause the vehicle to sway from side to side.

question: What action should a driver take if the engine in their vehicle cuts out suddenly when they are driving along?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: If the engine in the vehicle you are driving cuts out signal and steer to the side of the road. Switch on the hazard warning lights and contact the relevant breakdown service to get assistance.
questions: Check that the handbrake is fully off.
Signal and steer the car to the side of the road.
Engage a lower gear.
Depress the accelerator and then release it.
answer: Signal and steer the car to the side of the road.

question: How would hydraulic power steering be affected if an engine stalled in slow-moving traffic?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: Hydraulic power steering is operated by a pump which is driven by the engine. If the engine stalls, the pump stops working, and the steering becomes heavy and requires much more effort to turn.
questions: The steering becomes easier to operate.
The steering would become heavy and difficult to operate.
The vehicle would not move.
The vehicle would move faster.
answer: The steering would become heavy and difficult to operate.

question: What should a driver do if the accelerator jams when they are driving along?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: If the accelerator on the vehicle you are driving jams, select neutral and use the brakes to bring the vehicle to a safe halt. Switch off the engine as soon as the vehicle has stopped. Get the vehicle checked out before attempting to drive again.
questions: Engage a low gear and depress the clutch.
Leave the vehicle in gear and apply the brakes.
Try and flick the accelerator and the brakes with your foot.
Engage a neutral gear and apply the brakes.
answer: Engage a neutral gear and apply the brakes.

question: When driving on the road, what should a driver do if the brakes on their vehicle fail?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: If the brakes on the vehicle you are driving fade or fail, select a lower gear to slow the vehicle down and move to the left to come to a halt. You can also try to regain some braking by pumping the footbrake. This may help you the vehicle to a safe
questions: Check that the handbrake if fully off.
Engage neutral gear.
Engage a lower gear.
Engage a higher gear.
answer: Engage a lower gear.

question: When driving on the road, what should a driver do if the brakes on their vehicle fail?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: If the brakes on the vehicle you are driving fade or fail, select a lower gear to slow the vehicle down and move to the left to come to a halt. You can also try to regain some braking by pumping the footbrake. This may help you the vehicle to a safe
questions: Press the footbrake firmly then release it.
Pump the brake pedal rapidly.
Signal to following traffic to overtake you.
Use a hand signal to following traffic that you intend to slow down or stop.
answer: Pump the brake pedal rapidly.

question: When driving along, a driver feels that the oncoming car may crash into their vehicle. What should they do?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: If there is an oncoming vehicle in your path, flash your lights and sound your horn to alert the other driver. Bring your vehicle to a halt immediately.
questions: Apply the footbrake gently to bring the vehicle to a halt.
Flash the headlights and sound the horn to attract the attention of the other driver.
Apply the handbrake immediately to help bring the car to a halt.
Switch off the engine ignition to help bring the vehicle to a halt.
answer: Flash the headlights and sound the horn to attract the attention of the other driver.

question: When driving along and confronted by an obstacle, what should a driver do?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: To stop your vehicle in an emergency. apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping. Vehicles are fitted with braking systems to stop the vehicle.
questions: Apply the footbrake and switch off the ignition.
Apply the handbrake and the footbrake together.
Switch off the ignition.
Apply the footbrake firmly.
answer: Apply the footbrake firmly.

question: When driving along and required to stop suddenly, what should a driver do?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: To stop your vehicle in an emergency. apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping. Vehicles are fitted with braking systems to stop the vehicle.
questions: Steer sharply to one side and apply the handbrake.
Depress the clutch and apply the footbrake.
Apply the footbrake firmly.
Apply the handbrake and footbrake.
answer: Apply the footbrake firmly.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign gives advance warning of a series of bumps or hollows ahead. You should reduce your speed accordingly.
questions: Series of bumps or hollows ahead.
Rumble strips ahead.
Industrial estate ahead.
Steep hills ahead.
answer: Series of bumps or hollows ahead.

question: When required to stop in an emergency, what should a driver do?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: To stop your vehicle in an emergency. apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping. Vehicles are fitted with braking systems to stop the vehicle.
questions: Press and release the footbrake.
Maintain firm pressure on the footbrake.
Maintain a frim grip on the steering and depress both the clutch and footbrake.
Flash the headlights and the brake-lights.
answer: Maintain firm pressure on the footbrake.

question: When required to stop in an emergency. what should a driver do?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: To stop your vehicle in an emergency. apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping. Vehicles are fitted with braking systems to stop the vehicle.
questions: Switch off the A.B.S system.
Press the footbrake and engage a higher gear.
Depress the clutch pedal and engage a lower gear.
Press the footbrake firmly.
answer: Press the footbrake firmly.

question: What should a driver do to avoid having to make an emergency stop?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: When driving in traffic, read the road ahead and keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front Use the two-second rule to determine your safe distance from the vehicle in front.
questions: Drive with your left foot covering the brake-pedal.
Drive with your left foot covering the clutch pedal.
Keep your left-hand available to apply the handbrake.
Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front.
answer: Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front.

question: What should a driver do to avoid having to make an emergency stop?
heading: Uncategorized
explanation: Explantion: When driving in traffic, read the road ahead and keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front Use the two-second rule to determine your safe distance from the vehicle in front.
questions: Drive with your left foot covering the brake-pedal.
Scan the road well ahead.
Drive with your left foot covering the clutch pedal.
Keep your left-hand available to apply the handbrake.
answer: Scan the road well ahead.

question: What does a white line in the centre of the road mean?
heading: Alert Driving and Consideration
explanation: Explantion: You must not not cross or straddle a continuous white line in the center of the road unless you wish to enter land or premises and it is safe to do so.
questions: Vehicles may cross the line for a short time.
Vehicles may park during daylight hours only.
Vehicles may not cross or straddle the line.
Vehicles may perform a U-turn.
answer: Vehicles may not cross or straddle the line.

question: What does a continuous white line along the centre of the road mean?
heading: Alert Driving and Consideration
explanation: Explantion: You must never do a U-turn on any stretch of road with a continuous white line along its centre. The restricted vision at such places would make doing a U-turn very unsafe.
questions: No U-turn allowed.
Motorcyclists can overtake.
Parking allowed during business hours.
U-turn allowed during daylight hours.
answer: No U-turn allowed.

question: What should a driver do at an amber traffic light?
heading: Alert Driving and Consideration
explanation: Explantion: By law you must stop at an amber traffic light if it is safe to do.
questions: Continue only if sure that the junction is clear of pedestrians.
Make sure to pass the lights before they turn red.
Continue as there is not traffic at the junction.
Stop at the line unless it is not safe to do so.
answer: Stop at the line unless it is not safe to do so.

question: When driving on a road with tram lines why should a driver take extra care?
heading: Alert Driving and Consideration
explanation: Explantion: Different surfaces can affect your vehicle's grid on the road and its stopping distances. You should be aware of this when driving on different surfaces.
questions: Driving on tracks can improve braking.
Driving on tracks can improve steering
Driving on tracks can reduce tyre grip.
Driving on tracks can improve tyre grid.
answer: Driving on tracks can reduce tyre grip.

question: What must a driver be aware of before entering a roundabout?
heading: Characteristics of Various Types of Road
explanation: Explantion: When you enter a roundabout, you must give way to traffic already on the roundabout approaching from your right. Do not enter a roundabout if by doing so you would force another vehicle to slow down or stop.
questions: Traffic coming from behind - how fast it's travelling and how close it is.
The traffic to the right - how fast it's travelling and how close it is.
The traffic coming from the left - how fast it's travelling and how close it is.
The traffic ahead - how fast it's travelling and how close it is.
answer: The traffic to the right - how fast it's travelling and how close it is.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign gives advance warning that there might be a danger of skidding because of an uncertain road surface ahead.
questions: Steep hill ahead.
Crosswinds ahead.
Series of bends ahead.
Slippery stretch of road ahead.
answer: Slippery stretch of road ahead.

question: When a driver is driving in a line of traffic and does not intend to overtake, what should the driver do?
heading: Driver Behaviour and Anticipation
explanation: Explantion: You should always allow sufficient distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front. This will enable you so stop safely if necessary, and it will give overtaking vehicles enough room to pull in safely to the left after they have passed you.
questions: Beckon to the following traffic to overtake.
Drive close to the vehicle in front.
Stay back and leave a gap for other drivers to overtake.
indicate left as a signal to the following traffic to overtake.
answer: Stay back and leave a gap for other drivers to overtake.

question: How does wet weather affect a vehicle’s engine performance?
heading: Driving Risk Factors Related to Various Road Conditions
explanation: Explantion: Wet weather does not affect the performance of the vehicle's engine. It does, however, affect the vehicle's road holding and braking distances. It can also affect a driver's observations.
questions: It causes the engine to run at a higher temperature.
It has not affect on power output.
It causes the engine to run at a lower temperature.
It reduces the power output.
answer: It has not affect on power output.

question: What should a driver do where a section of road ahead has a shallow flooded area?
heading: Driving Risk Factors Related to Various Road Conditions
explanation: Explantion: When you approach a stretch of road with shallow flooding, you should reduce your speed and assess the area for any danger. As you drive through surface water, you should think of pedestrians and cyclists and try not splash them as you pass.
questions: Use a high gear and maintain the same speed.
Use a low gear and maintain the same speed.
Increase speed and use a higher gear.
Reduce speed and use a lower gear.
answer: Reduce speed and use a lower gear.

question: What should a driver do when driving on a wide road behind a vehicle that has signalled to turn right ahead?
heading: Observation/Field of View
explanation: Explantion: You may overtake on the left when the driver in front has moved out and signalled their intent to turn right and you are going straight ahead - provided there is enough room to do so safely and and your path will not be obstructed by the swing of a large vehicle turning right.
questions: Overtake on the left-hand side and carry on.
Overtake on the right-hand side and carry on.
Overtake on the left, but only if turning left a short distance ahead.
Stay behind and tap the brakes to signal other drivers to slow down.
answer: Overtake on the left-hand side and carry on.

question: What does this road marking mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: A single continuous white line along the centre of the road means all traffic must keep to the left of the line. You are not permitted to overtake or perform a U-turn on this section of road.
questions: Drivers must keep left of the continuous white line.
Drivers may cross the line to overtake.
Only motorcyclists may cross the lines to overtake.
Oncoming traffic may cross the line to overtake.
answer: Drivers must keep left of the continuous white line.

question: What can cause a vehicle to skid?
heading: Taking Emergency/Corrective Action
explanation: Explantion: Using harsh acceleration at the wrong time can cause a vehicle to skid, especially if the road is wet.
questions: Using harsh acceleration.
Stopping the vehicle in third gear.
Steering wheel too free.
Low tyre pressure.
answer: Using harsh acceleration.

question: At traffic lights a driver should take particular care for which road users coming up on the left?
heading: Vulnerable Road Users
explanation: Explantion: Before moving off at traffic lights you should be aware of cyclists and motorcyclists coming up on the left - in particular where there is an advanced stop line for cyclists ahead of that for other road users.
questions: Vans.
Motorcyclists.
Cars.
Trucks.
answer: Motorcyclists.

question: What should a driver be aware of when making a left-hand turn?
heading: Vulnerable Road Users
explanation: Explantion: When you are turning left, you should be aware that cyclists and pedestrians may come up on your inside. Always check to your left before you make a left turn.
questions: Following traffic must have room to overtake.
To approach with the nearside wheels brushing against the kerb.
Cyclists might come up on the outside.
Cyclists might come up on the inside.
answer: Cyclists might come up on the inside.

question: When may the holder of a Category W Learner Permit carry a passenger on a tractor or works vehicle?
heading: Safety Factors Relating to Vehicle and Persons Carried
explanation: Explantion: The holder of a category W license may carry a passenger in the vehicle only if: 1. The vehicle is designed to take a passenger, and 2. the passenger has held a full driving license in category W for two or more years.
questions: When the passenger has personal insurance cover.
When there is a need for their assistance.
When the passenger holds a full category M license and has personal insurance cover.
When there is proper passenger seating and the passenger holds a full category W license.
answer: When there is proper passenger seating and the passenger holds a full category W license.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign gives advance warning of a junction with roads of equal importance ahead. At this type of junction you should yield to traffic approaching from the right and traffic already turning.
questions: Railway crossing ahead.
Crossroads ahead with roads of equal importance.
Major road ahead.
Crossroads ahead with roads of less importance.
answer: Crossroads ahead with roads of equal importance.

question: What does this sign mean?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign gives advance warning of an open water area ahead. You should show caution in this situation.
questions: Road liable to flooding.
Steep descent ahead.
Unprotected quay, canal, or river ahead.
Slippery road ahead.
answer: Unprotected quay, canal, or river ahead.

question: What does this sign mean when displayed on approach to a motorway?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign is used at motorway toll plazas to direct traffic into a lane where the toll charge may be paid by putting the exact change into a coin basket. This lane usually has a height barrier fitted to prevent large vehicle using it. This lane is generally a quicker way through the toll plaza than the cashier lane. No change is given at such lanes.
questions: Coin basket on this lane
Ticket dispenser in this lane.
Leisure area on the left.
Cashier in this lane.
answer: Coin basket on this lane

question: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a motorway?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: This sign is used at motorway toll plazas to direct traffic into a lane where the toll charge is collected electronically. 4 out of 10
answer: 4 out of 10

question: Which of the following checks should a driver perform on their vehicle before moving off?
heading: Getting On or Off the Vehicle
explanation: Explantion: Before moving off it is advised to perform the ‘Safety Checks’ which includes the checking that all doors are safely closed.
questions: Ensure that the hazard warning lights are on.
Ensure that the interior of the vehicle is clean.
Ensure that all doors are properly secured.
Ensure that the windows are closed.
answer: Ensure that all doors are properly secured.

question: What advice should a driver give to passengers before opening doors?
heading: Getting On or Off the Vehicle
explanation: Explantion: Before opening any doors, check for other road users nearby, in particular motorcyclists and pedestrians.
questions: Check all around and open door with caution.
Make sure that you have proper clothing protection on.
Remove seat belt and exit vehicle immediately.
Leave windows slightly open to allow circulation of air.
answer: Check all around and open door with caution.

question: How do you make sure your vehicle is parked safely?
heading: Getting On or Off the Vehicle
explanation: Explantion: When parking make sure you do not interfere with normal traffic flow and that your vehicle does not disturb, block or endanger other road users.
questions: Don’t park it where it may endanger other road users.
Park your vehicle opposite another vehicle on a narrow road.
Avoid reversing your vehicle into a space.
Drive into parking space as quickly as possible.
answer: Don’t park it where it may endanger other road users.

question: What should be considered when reversing out of a parking space?
heading: Getting On or Off the Vehicle
explanation: Explantion: Some car parks are designed for you to park forwards to make it easier to load shopping. In these cases take extra care as you reverse out of the parking space because pedestrians and vehicles may pass behind you.
questions: Always reverse quickly to get out of space.
Avoid switching on your rear wiper.
Check behind using interior rear view mirror only.
Check for pedestrians and vehicles all around.
answer: Check for pedestrians and vehicles all around.

question: During what time periods can a driver be tested for drugs at a road side checkpoint?
heading: Drugs and Alcohol
explanation: Explantion: The law allows for a driver to be tested at any time for drugs after a crash, if you have committed a driving offence or if a Garda forms the opinion that you have consumed an intoxicant such as alcohol or certain drugs. The time of day has no bearing on what test can take place and it is an offence to refuse to perform impairment tests.
questions: Only during daylight hours.
Anytime of day or night.
Only during night time hours.
Only after an accident.
answer: Anytime of day or night.

question: Which statement is true about tyre pressure and driving on a motorway?
heading: Characteristics of Various Types of Road
explanation: Explantion: You should ensure that the tyre pressure of your vehicle is correct at all times. Correct tyre pressure is especially important when travelling long distances, on motorways and at speed.
questions: The driver should increase tyre pressure in order to cope with sustained high speed.
The driver should reduce tyre pressure because high speeds will cause them to heat up.
The driver should ensure that tyre pressure is normal.
The driver should increase the front tyre pressure.
answer: The driver should ensure that tyre pressure is normal.

question: What is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a trailer on national primary roads?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: When towing a trailer on a national primary road, it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h — exceeding this speed will make the vehicle unstable.
questions: 80 km/h.
60 km/h.
answer: 80 km/h.

question: What is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a trailer on a motorway?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: When towing a trailer on a motorway it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h — excessive speed will make such a vehicle unstable.
questions: 60 km/h.
80 km/h.
answer: 80 km/h.

question: When is it recommended to use coolant?
heading: Technical Matters with a Bearing on Road Safety
explanation: Explantion: The purpose of coolant is to keep the engine cool during operation. Coolant is usually a mixture of water and anti-freeze — this ensures that the coolant does not freeze in very cold weather.
questions: Summer only.
Winter only.
All year round.
In petrol engines only.
answer: All year round.

question: What effect could incorrectly aligned headlights have?
heading: Technical Matters with a Bearing on Road Safety
explanation: Explantion: A driver should ensure their headlights are properly aligned so as not to dazzle oncoming drivers and also to see properly themselves.
questions: They could reduce battery life.
They could cause a fire.
They could dazzle oncoming drivers.
They could wear out the bulbs prematurely.
answer: They could dazzle oncoming drivers.

question: What traffic may drive along on a cycle lane accompanied by a continuous white line?
heading: Traffic Signs and Regulatory Matters
explanation: Explantion: A cycle track is for the use of cyclists and motorised wheelchairs. No other vehicles may cross into or over a mandatory cycle track unless this is necessary in order to leave a side road or a property adjacent to the cycle track.
questions: Cyclists and taxis.
Cyclists and motorised wheelchairs.
Buses and cyclists.
Cyclists and motorcyclists.
answer: Cyclists and motorised wheelchairs.

question: When turning left into a side road, what should a driver do?
heading: Vulnerable Road Users
explanation: Explantion: When you are turning left, you should be aware that cyclists and pedestrians may come up on your inside. Always check to your left before you make a left turn.
questions: Ensure that following traffic has room to overtake if necessary.
Check for pedestrians or cyclists who may have come up on the ‘inside’.
Expect that traffic coming out of the other road will stay back and allow you space.
Approach the junction with the nearside wheels brushing against the kerb.
answer: Check for pedestrians or cyclists who may have come up on the ‘inside’.
